item.title: A Collector Follows His Nose Through the Maze of Modern Art
item.media:description: The art collector Sylvio Perlstein at home in Paris. Works from his vast selection of modern art will be on view in New York this month. (The photographer shot through gels and glass to achieve the effects shown in the portraits.)
item.media:credit: Paul Rousteau for The New York Times
item.description: Sylvio Perlstein’s accumulations of avant-garde art from the past 50 years comes to Hauser & Wirth this month.
item.dc:creator: ARTHUR LUBOW

item.title: Review: A ‘Carousel’ That Spins on a Romantically Charged Axis
item.media:description: Jessie Mueller as Julie Jordan and Joshua Henry as Billy Bigelow in the revival of “Carousel.”
item.description: Jack O’Brien and Justin Peck’s heartfelt, half-terrific revival of an American classic stars a wonderfully ambivalent Joshua Henry and Jessie Mueller.
item.dc:creator: BEN BRANTLEY

item.title: The Gladiators of ‘Scandal’ Leave the Arena
item.media:description: In Olivia Pope, as portrayed by Kerry Washington (left), Shonda Rhimes (right) created one of the most memorable antiheroes, let alone one of the more complex black characters, on television.
item.media:credit: Ryan Pfluger for The New York Times
item.description: As “Scandal” heads toward its finale, Shonda Rhimes, the show’s creator, and three of its stars discuss its craziest twists, its nuanced handling of racial issues and its legacy.
item.dc:creator: SALAMISHAH TILLET

item.title: How an Anxious-Adolescent Musical (No, Not That One) Found Its Fans
item.media:description: Will Connolly (center) as a high school student who takes steps to turn cool in the Two Rivers Theater production of “Be More Chill.”
item.description: “Be More Chill” played a month at a New Jersey theater, and nothing much happened. Then the internet got very busy.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH VINCENTELLI

item.title: Janice Dickinson at Cosby Trial: ‘Here Was America’s Dad on Top of Me’
item.media:description: The former model Janice Dickinson, 63, testified at Bill Cosby’s sexual assault retrial, telling the jury that the entertainer had drugged and raped her in 1982.
item.description: The former model says Bill Cosby drugged her then assaulted her in a hotel room in Lake Tahoe, but his defense team suggests she is making it up.
item.dc:creator: GRAHAM BOWLEY and JON HURDLE

item.title: Review: In ‘Zama,’ Trying to Say Goodbye (Cruel) New World
item.media:description: On the edge of the world: Daniel Giménez Cacho as Don Diego de Zama in Lucrecia Martel’s “Zama.”
item.description: In Lucrecia Martel’s “Zama,” an 18th-century magistrate in the Americas desperately tries to leave a cruel, cruelly comic world he has helped make.
item.dc:creator: MANOHLA DARGIS

item.title: Review: ‘Grace Jones: Bloodlight and Bami’ Finds the Model, Singer, Actress, Person
item.media:description: Grace Jones in the documentary “Grace Jones: Bloodlight and Bami.”
item.description: Grace Jones has always been an iconoclast. But this documentary restores her humanity.
item.dc:creator: WESLEY MORRIS

item.title: A Word With: For Neil Patrick Harris, It Takes an Adult to Make a Kids’ Show
item.media:description: Neil Patrick Harris
item.media:credit: Benjamin Norman for The New York Times
item.description: Mr. Harris talks about turning himself into the villainous Count Olaf in “A Series of Unfortunate Events” and about how he’s raising his own twins.
item.dc:creator: KATHRYN SHATTUCK
item.category: A Series of Unfortunate Events (TV Program)

item.title: Art Review: A Sci-Fi Showdown at the Met Museum’s Rooftop Garden
item.media:description: Drama on the deck: The artist Huma Bhabha’s installation for the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s Roof Garden, opening Tuesday, is “We Come in Peace.” The title comes from “The Day the Earth Stood Still,” and the two sculptures could stand for any balance of power or meeting.
item.media:credit: George Etheredge for The New York Times
item.description: The figures in “We Come in Peace,” by Huma Bhabha, suggest hopeful connections among languages, civilizations and even galaxies.
item.dc:creator: MARTHA SCHWENDENER

item.title: Yesterday in Styles: Wait, New Jersey Was Once Not Cool?
item.description: For years a punch line to snooty New Yorkers, New Jersey came into its own as a cultural hub in the 1990s, thanks to Lauryn Hill, Kevin Smith and “The Sopranos.”
item.dc:creator: ALEX WILLIAMS

item.title: ‘Incredibles 2’ Trailer: When a Superhero Is Also a Working Mom
item.description: The voices of Holly Hunter, Craig T. Nelson, Sarah Vowell and Samuel L. Jackson are back in the sequel to the 2004 original.
item.dc:creator: BRUCE FRETTS

item.title: ‘Roseanne’: When a Punch Line Feels Like a Gut Punch
item.media:description: Roseanne Barr and John Goodman in “Roseanne.”
item.description: Contrary to what Roseanne told Dan, maybe we’re not all caught up, says network sitcom writer Kelvin Yu.
item.dc:creator: KELVIN YU

item.title: Britney Spears and Jim Parsons Among Top Honorees at Glaad Awards
item.media:description: Britney Spears, at the Glaad Media Awards at The Beverly Hilton Hotel. She received the Vanguard Award, for an entertainer who has gone above and beyond to promote equality.
item.description: The awards ceremony, now in its 29th year, honors media efforts to fairly and accurately represent members of the L.G.B.T. community.
item.dc:creator: SOPAN DEB
item.category: Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation

item.title: Protest-Hit Director Quits Berlin Theater
item.media:description: Chris Dercon, who had an international pedigree as a former director of contemporary art museums including Tate Modern in London, led the Berlin Volksbühne theater for less than a year.
item.description: Chris Dercon, a former director of Tate Modern in London, led the Volksbühne theater for less than a year, facing bitter arguments over his vision.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Streaming: Turning Points: Three Movies Centering on Young Women
item.media:description: Elvire Emanuelle plays a teenager who joins a Brooklyn high school wrestling team in “First Match.”
item.description: Three movies about young women: “First Match,” “Layla M.” and “Ladies First,” all on Netflix.
item.dc:creator: GLENN KENNY

item.title: When Superheroes Battle Evil, Why Does Washington Always Lose?
item.media:description: Anthony Mackie, left, and Chris Evans in “Captain America: The Winter Soldier,” the rare superhero movie with glimpses of Washington.
item.description: The nation’s capital is rarely the site of climactic confrontations. The reasons range from comic-book history to Hollywood antagonism.
item.dc:creator: EMILY COCHRANE

item.title: Lucrecia Martel: A Director Who Confounds and Thrills
item.media:description: Lucrecia Martel at her home in Buenos Aires. “Romantic comedies are my enemy,” she said.
item.media:credit: Diego Levy for The New York Times
item.description: Argentina’s leading filmmaker specializes in elusive, off-kilter work. In person, she’s much blunter.
item.dc:creator: J. HOBERMAN

item.title: Best of Late Night: Trevor Noah Hammers Congress for Dependence on Facebook’s Cash
item.media:description: “Basically, Congress has to deal with big corporations the way rich white people punish their kids,” Trevor Noah said.
item.description: On “The Daily Show,” Mr. Noah said that Congress handles Facebook “the way rich white people punish their kids.”
item.dc:creator: GIOVANNI RUSSONELLO
item.category: Late Show with Stephen Colbert (TV Program)
The Daily Show with Trevor Noah (TV Program)

item.title: Betting on the Berkshires
item.media:description: Andrew Berens, a biotechnology analyst at Morgan Stanley in New York, bought an 8,200-square-foot Queen Anne-style house in the village of Housatonic that he and his sons use as a base for skiing at Butternut in the winter and taking in concerts at Tanglewood in the summer.
item.media:credit: Preston Schlebusch for The New York Times
item.description: Urban transplants like the former Guggenheim director Thomas Krens think Berkshire County, Mass., has untapped potential. So do real estate developers.
item.dc:creator: TIM McKEOUGH

item.title: Review: Jonas Kaufmann Takes a Big Step Toward ‘Tristan’
item.media:description: The tenor Jonas Kaufmann, left, trying out a substantial chunk of Wagner’s “Tristan und Isolde” at Carnegie Hall with Andris Nelsons, right, and the Boston Symphony Orchestra on Thursday at Carnegie Hall.
item.description: The star tenor sang a substantial excerpt from Wagner’s opera for the first time with the Boston Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall.
item.dc:creator: ANTHONY TOMMASINI

item.title: An Illustrated Tribute to ‘The Adventures of Pinocchio’
item.description: Sergio García Sánchez reimagines the 19th-century tale of a puppet who dreams of becoming a real boy.
item.dc:creator: SERGIO GARCIA SANCHEZ

item.title: An Opera Worth Fighting Over
item.description: Listen to Rameau’s rarely performed “Hippolyte et Aricie”
item.dc:creator: GEORGE LOOMIS

item.title: Nonfiction: The Amazing Life of a Robber Baron’s Daughter-in-Law, With Caveats
item.media:description: Florence Gould
item.media:credit: Courtesy of the Library of Congress
item.description: Susan Ronald’s “A Dangerous Woman” is an energetic biography of Florence Gould and a terrific window into the life of the superaffluent.
item.dc:creator: KAREN KARBO
item.category: A Dangerous Woman: American Beauty, Noted Philanthropist, Nazi Collaborator -- The Life of Florence Gould (Book)

item.title: Nonfiction: Why American Pragmatists Saved Postwar Europe
item.media:description: A demonstration in Paris against the Marshall Plan.
item.description: Benn Steil’s “The Marshall Plan” depicts the complicated politics and colorful cast of statesmen, spies and economists behind America’s intervention in midcentury Europe.
item.dc:creator: TIMOTHY NAFTALI

item.title: Nonfiction: A New Look at the New Deal’s Legacy of Public Housing
item.media:description: Chicago’s Cabrini-Green housing project in the 1960s.
item.media:credit: Chicago History Museum, via Getty Images
item.description: Ben Austen’s “High-Risers” assesses the dire consequences of segregated low-income residential developments across the nation.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD ROTHSTEIN
item.category: High-Risers: Cabrini-Green and the Fate of American Public Housing (Book)

item.title: The Shortlist: How Endangered Is American Democracy?
item.description: Four new books discuss current threats to our political system.
item.dc:creator: ARI BERMAN
item.category: The People vs Democracy: Why Our Freedom Is in Danger and How to Save It (Book)

item.title: Is Stan Lee Being Held Prisoner by Real-Life Villains?
item.media:credit: Ryan Pfluger for The New York Times
item.description: The Hollywood Reporter published an investigation saying that Mr. Lee, 95, was the victim of elder abuse. We visited the Marvel Comics creator at his home. “Nobody has more freedom,” he said.
item.dc:creator: BEN WIDDICOMBE

item.title: Fiction: In Stories About Slavery and Its Legacy, Hints of the Author’s Life
item.media:description: John Edgar Wideman
item.description: John Edgar Wideman brings a potent mix of the personal, political and historical to his new collection, “American Histories.”
item.dc:creator: MARTHA SOUTHGATE

item.title: Paperback Row
item.description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.
item.dc:creator: JOUMANA KHATIB

item.title: Inside the List: Turning Basketball Lovers Into Book Lovers, a Stanza at a Time
item.media:description: Kwame Alexander
item.description: Kwame Alexander’s last novel — “The Crossover,” a Newbery-winning, hip-hop- inflected tale of sports-loving twin boys — was written in verse. So is his new one, a prequel called “Rebound.”
item.dc:creator: TINA JORDAN

item.title: Our Back Pages: Notes From the Book Review Archives
item.description: In which we consult the Book Review’s past to shed light on the books of the present. This week: corporate tyranny in Richard Powers’s “Gain.”

item.title: Fiction: ‘The Silence of the Lambs’ Goes Nordic Noir
item.description: In Lars Kepler’s latest thriller, “The Sandman,” two Swedish cops can only crack their case by befriending an imprisoned serial killer.
item.dc:creator: KEN TUCKER

item.title: Ivory Tower: Should Anthropologists Judge the People They Study?
item.description: Three new books tackle the ethical dilemmas of ethnographers who immerse themselves in other cultures.
item.dc:creator: JAMES RYERSON
item.category: How To Think Like an Anthropologist (Book)

item.title: Fiction: The House May Be Haunted. But in This Novel, Commitment Is Scarier.
item.description: In Ben Dolnick’s “The Ghost Notebooks,” a young husband and wife find secrets lurking beneath the cozy charm of their new country home.
item.dc:creator: JOHN SEARLES

item.title: Children’s Books: When the Going Gets Tough, These Kids Find Their Way
item.description: In books by Varian Johnson, Vera Brosgol and others, kids aren’t spared life’s hardships. But they solve mysteries, handle smelly camp latrines and more.
item.dc:creator: NALINI JONES
item.category: Ivy Aberdeen's Letter to the World (Book)

item.title: Fiction: The Turbulent Life of the Small-Town Librarian
item.description: In Sue Halpern’s novel “Summer Hours at the Robbers Library,” a woman with a past takes a quiet job in a quiet town.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE WILDGEN
item.category: Summer Hours at the Robbers Library (Book)

item.title: Letters to the Editor
item.description: Readers respond to recent issues of the Sunday Book Review.

item.title: Crime: Solving Crimes the Old-Fashioned Way
item.description: Three brainy investigators (Lincoln Rhyme, Amos Walker and Bernie Gunther) and an apprentice sleuth (Daniel Pitt) track down some canny killers.
item.dc:creator: MARILYN STASIO

item.title: Ancient Tales for Modern Times
item.media:description: A scene from “Ithaque: Notre Odyssée 1” by Christiane Jatahy at the Odéon theater in Paris.
item.description: Three theatrical productions in Paris show that legends can still speak to audiences today.
item.dc:creator: LAURA CAPPELLE

item.title: The Personal Data of 346,000 People, Hung on a Museum Wall
item.media:description: Last week, the authorities in Wuhan, China, ordered Deng Yufeng’s exhibition of personal data shut down after two days and began investigating him on suspicion of amassing the information illegally.
item.description: An artist is under investigation for an exhibit intended to highlight China’s lack of privacy protections and a public sense of futility.
item.dc:creator: SUI-LEE WEE and ELSIE CHEN

item.title: What’s on TV Friday: ‘Lost in Space’ and ‘Chef’s Table’
item.media:description: A scene from “Lost in Space.”
item.description: Netflix reboots a 1960s sci-fi series. And Wyatt Cenac hosts a docu-series exploring America’s most pressing issues.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW R. CHOW

item.title: Books News: British Book Publishers Fear Brexit Will Bring a U.S. Invasion
item.media:description: The London Book Fair at Olympia exhibition center in West Kensington teemed with British and European publishers and editors.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: A fight is looming between publishers in Britain and the United States. At stake: the lucrative European book market.
item.dc:creator: DAVID SEGAL

item.title: RuPaul’s Drag Race: ‘RuPaul’s Drag Race’ Season 10, Episode 4: RuPocalypse, Now?
item.media:description: A scene from “RuPaul’s Drag Race.”
item.description: When the world is coming to an end, why not throw a ball?
item.dc:creator: AMANDA DUARTE

item.title: Atlanta: ‘Atlanta’ Season 2, Episode 7 Recap: Drake Has Left the Building
item.media:description: Zazie Beetz in “Atlanta.”
item.description: After last week’s detour into the macabre, the show returned to more familiar territory: the Atlanta party scene.
item.dc:creator: LEIGH-ANN JACKSON

item.title: Review: A ‘King Lear’ in Which You Feel for All the Daughters
item.media:description: Antony Sher as King Lear in the Royal Shakespeare Company production directed by Gregory Doran at BAM Harvey Theater.
item.media:credit: Richard Termine for The New York Times
item.description: A mighty king demanding declarations of love faces villains you understand, in this Royal Shakespeare production at BAM.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH VINCENTELLI

item.title: Tony Rulings: ‘1984’ Can Vie for Best Play; Andrew Garfield and Nathan Lane Avoid Showdown
item.media:description: Reed Birney, second from right, and Tom Sturridge, kneeling, in the Broadway production of “1984.”
item.description: The committee on eligibility also decided that Glenda Jackson stood tallest of “Three Tall Women.”
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL PAULSON

item.title: By the Book: James B. Comey: By the Book
item.media:description: James B. Comey
item.description: When James B. Comey, the former F.B.I. director and author of “A Higher Loyalty,” reads fiction, it’s “almost always something my kids are reading, so I can … pretend to be cool.”

item.title: Nonfiction: James Comey Has a Story to Tell. It’s Very Persuasive.
item.media:description: James B. Comey testified to the House Intelligence Committee in March 2017. He was fired by the president on May 9.
item.description: In “A Higher Loyalty,” the former F.B.I. director doesn’t mince words in describing his interactions with President Trump: “This president is unethical, and untethered to truth.”
item.dc:creator: MICHIKO KAKUTANI
item.category: A Higher Loyalty: Truth, Lies, and Leadership (Book)
Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: Looming Ivory Ban Will Create a Mountain of Unsellable Antiques
item.media:description: An ivory netsuke of a rat from the 18th century.
item.description: Heirlooms like the ones in Edmund de Waal’s “The Hare With Amber Eyes” are set to become unsellable when Britain brings in new laws aimed at protecting elephants.
item.dc:creator: SCOTT REYBURN

item.title: Brothers Osborne Want to Bring Guitar Heroes Back to Nashville
item.media:description: T.J. and John Osborne have been carving out their own path in Nashville, focusing on rock-oriented music that’s shaggier than the sounds dominating country radio.
item.media:credit: Eric Ryan Anderson for The New York Times
item.description: T.J. and John Osborne once faced opposition swimming against the “bro country” tide. Now their brand of rock-oriented country is finding a wider audience.
item.dc:creator: JEWLY HIGHT

item.title: 10 Plays and Musicals to Go to in NYC This Weekend
item.media:description: A scene from “Flight,” which closes on April 21 at the McKittrick Hotel.
item.media:credit: Emon Hassan for The New York Times
item.description: Previews, openings and some last-chance picks.
item.dc:creator: ALEXIS SOLOSKI

item.title: 6 Comedy Shows to Catch in NYC This Weekend
item.media:description: Ilana Glazer, the Yas Queen of “Broad City,” will appear at “Regular Comedy” at Murmrr Ballroom on April 19.
item.description: Our guide to stand-up, improv and variety shows happening this weekend and in the week ahead.
item.dc:creator: KASIA PILAT

item.title: 14 Pop, Rock and Jazz Concerts to Check Out in NYC This Weekend
item.media:description: Joey Badass will play Terminal 5 on April 19.
item.media:credit: Jessica Lehrman for The New York Times
item.description: Our guide to pop and rock shows and the best of live jazz happening this weekend and in the week ahead.

item.title: 5 Dance Performances to See in NYC This Weekend
item.media:description: From left, Jon Boogz and Lil Buck, who will perform at N.Y.U. Skirball Center on Saturday.
item.description: Our guide to dance performances happening this weekend and in the week ahead.
item.dc:creator: BRIAN SCHAEFER

item.title: 8 Things to Do With Your Kids in NYC This Weekend
item.media:description: In “The Little Red Fish,” which will be playing at the Lion Theater every weekend until April 29, JeJe (center, maneuvered by members of the Puppet Kitchen) follows his piscine pet into the pages of a book.
item.description: Our guide to cultural events in New York City for children and teenagers happening this weekend and in the week ahead.
item.dc:creator: LAUREL GRAEBER

item.title: 8 Classical Music Concerts to See in NYC This Weekend
item.media:description: One of the finest duos in lieder, Mark Padmore (center right) and Paul Lewis, will perform at Alice Tully Hall on April 19.
item.media:credit: Tina Fineberg for The New York Times
item.description: Our guide to the city’s best classical music and opera happening this weekend and in the week ahead.
item.dc:creator: DAVID ALLEN

item.title: 3 Film Series to Catch in NYC This Weekend
item.media:description: From left, Kyo Machiko and Ganjiro Nakamura in Yasujiro Ozu’s “Floating Weeds,” showing on Friday at Japan Society as part of the Kazuo Miyagawa retrospective occurring there and at MoMA through April 29.
item.description: Our guide to film series and special screenings.
item.dc:creator: BEN KENIGSBERG

item.title: 25 Art Exhibitions to View in NYC This Weekend
item.media:description: An installation view of the Frick Collection’s “Zurbarán’s Jacob and His Twelve Sons: Paintings From Auckland Castle,” which closes on April 22.
item.description: Our guide to new art shows and some that will be closing soon.

item.title: The Enthusiast: In Praise of Margery Sharp
item.media:description: The author Margery Sharp in 1938, pictured as she arrived in New York from England aboard the S.S. Bremen.
item.description: For decades now, I have been browsing happily in her brilliantly acerbic fiction — social comedies that track issues of romance, sex, marriage, family, class and artistic endeavor through most of the 20th century.
item.dc:creator: PERRI KLASS, M.D.

item.title: Popcast: Cardi B Arrives at the Top
item.media:description: Cardi B’s debut album, “Invasion of Privacy,” is part of her broad-scale pop culture takeover.
item.description: The 25-year-old’s LP “Invasion of Privacy” is part of her broad-scale pop culture takeover. A conversation about her rise and debut album, on Popcast.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES
